docs.lead_paragraph: THE Supreme Court ruled this month that states had the right to insist on an independent review for patients whose managed health care plans refused to pay for a treatment or drug prescribed by their doctor. Congress has yet to pass a patients' bill of rights that would include independent reviews of medical disputes. However, 42 states and the District of Columbia currently have health care review laws. And most big managed-care companies now have some type of outside review process, according to the American Association of Health Plans, a trade group in Washington.

headline.main: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROBERT D. REISCHAUER; Better Medical Decisions, Not Higher Costs

docs.abstract: Interview with Urban Institute president Robert D Reischauer on Supreme Court ruling that states can insist on independent review for patients whose managed care plans refuse to pay for treatment or drug prescribed by doctor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Griffin lay on the waiting room floor at the veterinary hospital at the University of Pennsylvania, Sharlene Greene stroked his legs, looked him in the eyes and murmured endearments. Today was Griffin's day, the day the cast on the right front leg of the 9-month-old Irish wolfhound would be taken off. ''Thank goodness,'' Mrs. Greene said. ''I am glad the insurance is there.''

headline.main: Break a Leg, Fluffy, if You Have Insurance

docs.abstract: Article on pet insurance business in America, whose market has long been dominated by Veterinary Pet Insurance; company has reported eight-fold revenue growth to nearly $72 million this year, but is facing competition from foreign companies and American Kennel Club; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER the accounting problems at Enron, Adelphia Communications and now WorldCom, many investors may wonder whether they are reading fact or fiction when companies start to report second-quarter earnings. Mitch Zacks, director of research at Zacks Investment Research, a firm that tracks earnings estimates, talked last week about the coming reporting period. Following are excerpts from the conversation. Q. How do you assess the second quarter? A. Let's back up a minute first. In the first quarter, 60 percent of the companies that reported exceeded earnings estimates. Twenty percent were in line and 20 percent were lower than expected.

headline.main: 2nd Quarter Shapes Up Much Like The First

docs.abstract: Interview with Zacks Investment Research director Mitch Zacks on outlook for corporate earnings; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fourteen years after Eli Lilly introduced a small green and white capsule called Prozac, antidepressants have mushroomed from a modest market into a $12 billion industry. And Americans, little by little, are coming to think of depression as an illness like any other, a topic discussed on dates and at dinner parties. But the euphoria that greeted the arrival of the generation of drugs that Prozac heralded has faded.

headline.main: Antidepressants Lift Clouds, But Lose 'Miracle Drug' Label

docs.abstract: Euphoria that greeted arrival of new generation of antidepressant drugs when Eli Lilly introduced Prozac 14 years ago has faded; studies indicate while millions are helped by antidepressants, including estimated 35 to 45 percent of those who take them, 55 to 65 percent are not helped nearly as much; while some people experience no side effects, for others side effects make drugs unusable, or simply not worth trouble; many patients end up on merry-go-round of medication trials, switching repeatedly from one drug to another or combining drugs to maximize effects; market for antidepressants, which in 1998 grew by 24 percent, is expected to expand by only 5 percent in 2002--situation that has sent pharmaceutical companies scrambling to find new molecules that are more effective and have fewer side effects; companies are tweaking chemical structures of existing drugs and harnessing old standbys for new uses and marketing them for everything; anaylsts say industry needs new class of drugs, one that will have as much impact, clinically and financially, as Prozac did 14 years ago; graphs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Fourteen years after Eli Lilly introduced a small green and white capsule called Prozac, antidepressants have mushroomed from a modest market into a $12 billion industry. And Americans, little by little, are coming to think of depression as an...

docs.lead_paragraph: When the House voted early today to help elderly people buy prescription medicines, it was a major moment in the history of American health care and politics. The vote foreshadows a deepening federal commitment to the elderly and the aging baby boom generation, as well as a significant expansion in the role of government. Both parties laid claim to the title of being the best protectors of the elderly. Republicans hope to impose fiscal discipline on the proposed new program, but that will not be easy.
docs.abstract: House vote to add drug benefits to Medicare seen foreshadowing deepening federal commitment to elderly and aging baby boom generation and major expansion in government's role despite expected impasse on Medicare expansion this year; House debate suggests drug benefit is becoming inevitable (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The University of Colorado regents approved health care benefits for same-sex partners and their dependents after 15 years of debate on the issue. The 5-to-4 vote reverses a decision nine months ago to deny such benefits and makes the university the first state entity in Colorado to offer gay partner benefits to employees. The policy will take effect in November. Mindy Sink (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Victory For Same-Sex Partners

docs.abstract: University of Colorado regents, 5-4, reverse earlier decision and vote to make school first Colorado state entity to offer gay partner health benefits to employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today added two important cases on health care to the docket for its next term, including a closely watched case from Maine on the state's effort to force drug manufacturers to reduce their prices to Maine residents. Both new cases reflect efforts by state governments to move ahead with health care policy in the absence of action by Congress. The second case is a challenge to a Kentucky law, similar to laws on the books in half the states, that requires managed care plans to accept any doctor who meets their qualifications and who wants to join.

headline.main: Justices Accept Case on Maine's Drug Discount Program

docs.abstract: Supreme Court agrees to hear Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America appeal of Appeals Court ruling upholding Maine law that seeks to use federal Medicaid law as leverage with drug manufacturers and wholesalers to win negotiated discounts on prices paid by state residents who lack insurance coverage for drugs; agrees to hear managed care industry challenge to Kentucky law that requires managed care plans to accept any doctor who meets their qualifications and who wants to join; such laws, sought by doctors as protection against dismissal by plans for recommending too many treatments or complaining about conditions, have been passed by 25 states; plans hold limited pool of doctors is essential to holding down costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago this summer, my wife and I lost a baby. I say ''lost,'' as if we had misplaced it. There is nothing like abortion to make you appreciate the solace of euphemism. Lord knows the zealots who have occupied the field and mined it with moral explosives have left little room for comfort. Let's begin with what happened. At 17 weeks, we went to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City to view ultrasound pictures of our future child and have amniotic fluid drawn for testing. The ultrasound image showed that the fetus was not growing as fast as expected, and before long we had a couple of specialists puzzling over the pictures. Why was there so little fluid? Why was the placenta so large? Was there a defective chromosome? Were the kidneys missing?
docs.abstract: Bill Keller Op-Ed column on difficult choice he and wife made to abort stunted fetus late in pregnancy; holds ideologues on both sides of abortion debate too often treat decisions as if they were clear-cut and pain-free; says he is pro-choice, but now sees 'choice' as mixed blessing; urges moves to give parents of potentially defective fetus more information; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The financial community is better known for irrational exuberance than religious reverence. With its culture of hard-charging salesmen, bawdy camaraderie and liquid lunches, it has even been described as a godless place. But investors can now choose from several dozen religion-based mutual funds, created with the intent of keeping portfolios morally pure. In the case of one such fund, investors have also turned a handsome profit.

headline.main: Religion Journal; Putting Money Where Beliefs Are, Through 'Morally Pure' Mutual Funds

docs.abstract: Array of religion-based mutual funds, created with intent of keeping portfolios morally pure, avoid holdings in companies whose businesses or policies are opposed by various religious groups; portfolios are often directly opposite of those of better-known socially conscious mutual funds; successful investment performance of Ave Maria Catholic Fund noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States is pressing hard to resume assistance to the Indonesian military in an effort to re-establish American influence here in the world's most populous Muslim nation after nearly a decade of keeping its distance from the Indonesian Army because of its human rights abuses. The arrest here this month of a suspected operative of Al Qaeda strengthened the Bush administration's determination to re-engage with Indonesia's army, despite its lack of reform. The administration is using the arrest to support its argument that Indonesia, a reluctant partner in the crackdown on terrorism, should be rewarded for its support with military aid.

headline.main: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO RESUME AIDING INDONESIA'S ARMY
